description.text: This is a shoe designed to be created on a 3D printer using a hard plastic, although flexible and semi flexible of materials will improve comfort. The shoe is made from a 3D printed mesh fabric that prints flat and is then attached to the sole using zip ties. The sole is also flexible because of the hinge structure built into the foot bed. The current shoe is designed to be a child size 8 shoe. Scaling of this design may effect how well the zip ties fit in the sole. For each shoe you will need 1 sole, 1 upper, 1 toe and 2 buckles. Both left and right sole files have been included. When printing the fabric make sure it is rotated so it prints flat on the print bed.

This thing is a redesign of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1936202 . The original file did not allow enough clearance for the LED light with wires soldered to it to slide in at all. The lights used can be found here from BangGood: https://us.banggood.com/Wholesale-Warehouse-T10-5630-9SMD-LED-White-Light-Car-Canbus-Error-Free-Replacement-Light-Bulb-wp-Usa-989068.html ...... They are cheap and work great! Shipping was fast also!

Just solder 1 wire to each side of the LED and then slip them through the hole in the mount, routing the wires out of the side holes. If the wires are stiff coming through, just widen the hole a bit. After all of the lights are in place, clip them on to the rails at the bottom, then route the wires through the vent holes. Once the wires are routed, strip and solder 3 of the same leads together for each pole. These LEDs have no polarity, so there is no +/-, just make sure the same sides are soldered together. Once you have 2 sets of 3 wires together, solder one wire to each to make the connection over to the power supply. Crimp a connector on the end of the new leads, and attach one to the + and one to the - of the power supply where the case fan is attached. (the fan inside the base next to the power switch and plug). Turn the switch on and voila!

Any questions on assembly please reach out to me and I can assist. [email protected]

comments.text: I finally got around to installing these on my Rostock Max v3. Got it all wire up, put everything back together, ran the 'G29' calibration and...crash, the hot end hits the lights during the calibration. I ended up removing the lights from the towers and sitting them next to the towers, but back a little further and everything works OK. Luckily, I left enough wire underneath to move them a little bit.

description.text:
I setup a Raspberry Pi 3 to experiment with ROS, OpenCV, and whatever else I felt like looking into, and I wanted a desktop case for it. I started trying to duplicate the look of the Intel NUC stuff, but ended up doing a "micro" version of a desktop PC tower case.

The basic specs for the setup are:

  1. Raspberry Pi 3 with WD Pi drive (314GB) as the boot disk. (No SD card at all)
  2. Pi camera
  3. Adafruit audio amp driving stereo speakers (Okay, they are a bit close together.)
  4. Pi and HD LED's moved to the front panel.
  5. Adafruit 128x64 OLED display and four buttons. Used for menu system to start stuff, show status, and reboot/shutdown system.
  6. All Pi USB & Ethernet ports brought out to panel mount sockets.
  7. Pi serial console port connected to USB serial adapter on back panel.
  8. Variable speed cooling fan, speed based on CPU temp.
  9. Raspberry Pi logo on case side.
  10. Clear removable window on other case side.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm 2 extra shells

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The Pi logo overlay is printed at .2mm with 1 extra shell and 20% infill. All the other pieces as above.

Needed Parts
  1. Raspberry Pi 3 with WD Pi drive and camera
  2. 6" USB cable for Pi drive: https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16812423073
  3. 12" USB to panel mount: https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16812200475
  4. Two 6" USB tp anel mount: https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16812228774
  5. Adafruit Perma-Proto HAT for Pi: https://www.adafruit.com/product/2310
  6. Adafruit 1.3" 128x64 OLED display: https://www.adafruit.com/product/938
  7. Adafruit Stacking Header: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1979
  8. Adafruit stereo amp: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1552
  9. Adafruit 12" F-F jumper wires: https://www.adafruit.com/product/793
  10. Adafruit 6" F-F jumper wires: https://www.adafruit.com/product/266
  11. Adafruit RtAng 3.5mm Stereo to Pigtail: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1700
  12. 6 pcs 3mm x 10mm cap screws (To attach USB panel mounts)
  13. 25 pcs #2 x 3/8" screws (To assemble case & Pi/drive mounts.
  14. 8 pcs #2 x 14" screws for display and Pi
  15. 4 pcs #1 x 1/4" screws to mount the camera
  16. 4 pcs #2 x 1/2" screws to mount the feet
  17. 4 pcs #1 x 3/8" screws to mount the fan (Can use hot glue)
  18. FTDI UM232R USB to serial module (For Pi serial console): https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/ftdi-future-technology-devices-international-ltd/UM232R/768-1019-ND/1836397
  19. 5" of CAT5 cable
  20. Crimp on RJ45: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Ideal-RJ-45-8-Position-8-Contact-Category-5e-Modular-Plugs-25-per-Card-85-346/100012932
  21. RJ45 wall plate jack: http://www.homedepot.com/p/CE-TECH-Category-5e-Jack-White-10-Pack-5025-WH-10/204410618
  22. Two 29mm Mini speakers: https://www.radioshack.com/products/radioshack-8-ohm-mini-speaker
  23. Four SMT switches: https://www.radioshack.com/products/spst-12vdc-smt-tact-switch-1
    24: 5V 40mmx10.5mm fan: https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/orion-fans/OD4010-05MB/1053-1202-ND/2621107
  24. P2N2222A NPN transistor, or equivalent.
  25. 1.5K 1/4W resistor, leaded.
  26. 1N4001 Diode
  27. .1" header socket: https://www.adafruit.com/product/598

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed with 25% infill and 5 perimeters (perimeters is what gives rigidity).

Rotate the part to the correct position on the printbed.

Frag rack sections for saltwater tanks.

Fusion 360 .F3D file is also attached.

You use at least 2 Connecting Pieces to connect 2 sections of Egg Crate together.
Connecting Pieces are probably going to be friction-fit depending on the Settings you have used, but I still recommend Super-Glue.

You can use the Rod Holder - Square (basically a bushing to make a round rod fit in a square hole), with 1/2 Acrylic Rod. Again - I recommend super-glue.

The Square Bushing has a lot of clearance within the Egg Crate, it is not a friction fit. You can accidentally super-glue it quite off-level, but it also gives you more creative flexibility as a result.

Recommend 2 people to put this together with Glue, depending on your configuration.

I have also found that printing the Connector and Rod Holder with 0.1mm Layer Height gives best results. Using 0.24mm worked ok for me, on the Egg Crate itself.

Supports:

No

Fusion 360

I used Fusion 360. You can find the .F3D file attached if you want to play around and modify the design to suit your needs.

title: P&LE; McKees Rocks Locomotive Shop Wall V2.1

description.text:
My O scale model train layout represents the section of the Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad between McKees Rocks and Youngstown. This wall section (stretcher bond brick pattern) will let you assemble a background flat of the McKees Rocks Locomotive Shop.
This is version 2.1.

Many photos on the Internet, example:

https://www.flickr.com/photos/dwdavidson/4880853220

The representation of the white paint and the lettering should not be printed (select "no" for show_white_banner_and_name). They will have to be painted on the final objects.

The glass block windows should be separately printed in a transparent PLA and could be back lighted. To print just the glass block windows, select "no" for all show options except select "yes" for show_glassblockwindow.

You will need 9 high wall sections and 8 short wall sections. You can get a high wall section by selecting "yes" for all show options except for show_glassblockwindow and show_white_banner_and_name. This should give you a wall with side relief (double wythe), cornice, roof flashing and foundation. There should be an opening for the glass block windows with a sill (rowlock brick pattern) underneath and a concrete header block above.

For the short wall section, turn off the side relief, roof, and cornice. Change the number of brick courses to 106.

Of course, you can change around any of the options and values to get all kinds of different walls and brick sizes.

The 3/8" bedding may be too small to see when printed in HO or N scale. The wall itself might be too thin for a good print - O & G scale walls may be solid enough to print.

Uses Build Plate from the Thingiverse library.

Original development using OpenSCAD 2015.03-3 then moved to 2017.01.20

I've now completed the printing (for O scale) and assembly of the Shops. I made 4 tall sections and 3 short sections (rather than the 17 total on the original). In order to fit on my printer bed, I had to print each section in two pieces. The walls were spray painted in a red that looks like brick. The windows were printed in white PLA.

In front of the building in my layout photo is my fleet of P&LE diesel engines. All MTH (SW-1500, 2x GP-7, GP38-2, and U28B).

The name right now is letters printed on paper and attached to the building using double-sided tape. It follows the contour of the layers of brick. Someday (famous last words) I hope to spray paint the white on the bricks and use large decal letters. This font is close to the font used on the prototype but does not match exactly. I'll have to try to find out what font the P&LE used (maybe an NYC font?).

I've added the P&LE logo to Thingiverse here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2468652

My web page: http://www.silogic.com/trains/layout.html

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

0.1mm

20%

Notes:

Printing with 0.1mm resolution makes the prints take twice as long but with 0.2mm, the bricks did not look good (at least in O scale).

author: CliffCliff

title: Bowden tube clamp for Prometheus System

description.text:
I had some problems with bowden tubes starting to slip after few filament jams and trying to feed wrong filament to the Y-part. Also there's small play involved with the original tube clips on Prometheus extruder.
So I designed these clamps; the plate version replaces the acrylic part on the extruder on the output side and the small clamps are meant for the input side to stop the tube getting pulled to the extruder (happened to me once).

The included OpenSCAD file refers to modules that are defined in here: https://github.com/spegelius/Dollo

Printer:

FrankenCube with Prometheus System

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Supports are needed for the underside of the plate.
I used PLA, but should work with other materials too.

BOM/clamp

2x 10mm M3 screw
2x M3 nut

For Prometheus System, 2 plate clamps and 2 small clamps are needed

Assembly

Fit the M3 nuts in the indents. Slide the tube in, it can be tight fit depending how accurate the print is. Once in proper position, screw the M3 screws in and tighten. IT's good idea to test the tightness by sliding a piece of filament through to make sure it still moves without restrictions.

title: Makergear M2 Larger Electronics Box with 2 LM2596 Holders

description.text:
I have converted all the fans on my printer to 12v noctua fans for lower noise levels. Since the Printer pushes 24volts I needed 2 LM2596 Buck converters to convert the output to 12v. I also added active cooling fans to the X, Y, and Extruder motors and have added LED lights as well. I built a distribution block with 2 sides, one for the Fan0 Output and one for the Fan1 output filtered through the Buck Converters to convert to 12V. This larger electronics case accommodates the 2 LM2596 converters and a Radio Shack 276-150 Circuit Board which I built the distribution block on.

The top panel is divided into an upper and lower lid, the lower lid slides into a mount on the left side and lowers down with the right wall under the upper lid to keep it in place. The upper lid slides into a mount on the right side then has holes that line up with the case which can be attached with 2 M4(I think - extra screws from the M2 Kit) screws. The holes are tight enough you can screw directly into the plastic and it did hold for me, but there is also a slot to insert 2 M4 Lock nuts (also M2 extras). I used the lock nuts to ensure a hold even if the plastic strips over time. I have included 2 Lower lid files, one has a cutout to view the voltage on the 2 Buck Converters, the other one is solid and does not contain the cutouts in case you want to use the case without those converters. The pegs that they mount to can be broken off with pliers if you choose not to use them.

I have been using this case with no issues for a couple weeks. In regards to the amperage draw from the Fan1 and Fan0 - I have been using these accessories on the printer for about 5 months (printing almost daily) with no negative side effects. Below is a list of the accessories that I have attached to the printer

Fan1
Extruder Fan - Noctua 40mm
Case Fan - Noctua 40mm
Lighting - Peel and stick Roll of 12v white LEDs cut in 3 sections, 2 sections with 12 LEDs each mounted under the X axis frame, and one section with 3 LEDs mounted under the extruder Fan in a custom Fan Grill with LED holder.

Fan0
Bed Fan - 60mm Noctua in custom mount (see other designs)
3 Scythe Super Kaze 40mm fans for cooling the stepper motors (X, Y, and Extruder)

The distribution block has 1 open port still on the Fan0 Side, and I have tested it with an additional fan in the event I choose to upgrade to dual extruder. My Z motor never even gets warm.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Supports are needed for the Upper Lid Only due to the raised Fan mount - The fins on the grill are thin, be very careful removing support material.

I also used supports in the slots for the lock nuts on the case, but could probably print it without them only issue might be the upper hole may not be round

Printed with a .50 mm nozzle, but prints fine with other sizes as well, just a slower print.

Printed in PLA, 215C on the extruder and 60C on the bed. very easy print

In the Slicer you may need to rotate 90 degrees to get it to fit, it does take up nearly the entire X and Y print range on the M2, I did end up removing the bed clips for a few layers until i had clearance then i paused the print and put them back on

2 M4 locknuts slide into the case pilars, i used pliers to press them into the slots and they do not appear that they will ever come out, make sure they are lined up correctly before applying pressure.

author: Jferebee

title: Marking gaugeV2 - Adjustable and fixed width

description.text:
This is a simple marking gauge. It features two holes for marking beams. By printing two of the single pin marking beams you can use this as an adjustable marking gauge or a cutting gauge.

The fixed width marking beams are for marking mortise and tenons that are 6mm, 12mm, 20mm or 24mm in width. Of course you can use the two single pin marking beams to mark out mortise and tenons of any width.

This is an updated version of my first marking guage. This one uses wedges rather than 1/4" 20 bolts. The first version had its bolt holes to close together to use knobs. Another bonus is the fact that this requires less metal parts, just the marking pins (nail).

author: Boogie

description.text:
This is a weather station based on a Respberry Pi 3.
Weather informations are dealed from openweathermap.org (a free account is necessary to get an API Key).

The screen is an 4inch HDMI screen made by WaveShare and can be found there : https://fr.aliexpress.com/item/Raspberry-Pi-LCD-touchscreen-4-inch-800x480-IPS-hdmi-display-better-than-3-5-inch-touch/32811763632.html?ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_2_10152_10065_10151_10068_436_10136_10137_10157_10060_10138_10155_10062_10156_10154_10056_10055_10054_10059_10099_10103_10102_10096_10147_10052_10053_10142_10107_10050_10051_10084_10083_10080_10082_10081_10177_10110_10111_10112_10113_10114_10181_10183_10182_10185_10032_10078_10079_10077_10073_10070_10123,searchweb201603_4,ppcSwitch_5&btsid=7e87c829-3d9d-4802-89b7-5ad32439105b&algo_expid=43dfe1b6-76e2-498f-be9d-122c359bd377-6&algo_pvid=43dfe1b6-76e2-498f-be9d-122c359bd377

4 M3x22 are needed to close the box.

The python program and icons are in the zip file. (sorry for Python Gurus, this is my 1st Python program ^^)
Some configuration variables are at the top of the program (API Key, Display unit for temperature, months and days translations, refresh timeout for weather informations)

Don't forget to configure an ntmp server on the pi to get the right hour. It is also necessary to configure a Wifi connection on the Pi.

About 260 years ago, Benjamin Franklin designed a clock with one hand that told both the hours and minutes. You can read more about it here:
https://founders.archives.gov/documents/Franklin/01-08-02-0060

Franklin's design never caught on, but clocks based on it have been produced in limited quantities from time to time, for example, an electric version by Paragon in the 1960s, a weight-driven version by Thwaites and Reed in the 1970s, and a wrist watch by Meistersinger in 2015. For more information, see http://www.ablogtowatch.com/meistersinger-benjamin-franklin-watch/

My 3D printed version of the Franklin clock dial is very similar to other versions, except that I replaced the Roman numerals with conventional numerals. I designed it with raised lines and numerals so that I could color them with a sharpie after printing. The small dial is for the seconds hand.

comments.author: jodino

comments.text:
Unfortunately, you can't buy a mechanism for Franklin's clock. You'd have to build one, or modify an existing mechanism. There are some details of James Ferguson's mechanism for Franklin's clock on this page: https://founders.archives.gov/documents/Franklin/01-08-02-0060
That page will tell you how many teeth are on each gear, etc. If you have clock-making experience, this mechanism should be fairly easy to build.

title: Monoprice Mini v2 webcam bed mount c270

description.text:
Remixed / modified a bed mount for the monoprice mini v2. Using a logitech c270 as the webcam.

-Webcam cover and straight tripod arms taken from - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2267182
-Camera connector to the arms taken from - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1228521
-Focus ring taken from - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1406879
-Bed mount was remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1975739 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2267182 . I combined them in order to utilize the two extra holes that were not being utilized. It also has a small indentation for the y axis belt so it does not press up against it.

Wanted the option to move the webcam/arms both horizontally and vertically, So i made different versions of the bed mount and arms in order to customize to your liking.

Two versions of the bed mount:
-bed cam mount - has the connector going vertical - up and down.
-bed cam mount v2 - has the horizontal going - left and right.

Two versions of the arms:
-Tripod arms - simple one directional arms
-Arm pivot - flips the next connecting arm in other direction

I used some spare (4) 6/32 screws and (4) nuts to connect the mount onto the bed. Figure this would translate to 5mm (possibly). m3x20 screws to connect the arms

Webcam does shake a tad when the bed moves, but not too bad for taking timelapses or just streaming/viewing.

description.text:
I was looking for a iPhone holder for my car, the one that seemed to suit most of my requirements was this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:609134 but it didn't totally work.

I have a 2004 Jaguar X-type so I redesigned basically all elements of this to make it better fit the vehicle.

As the photos show, it still allows access to all the heater controls and the AC LCD screen, it blocks off the CD player controls but as this thing mounts in the CD slot, you wont be using them anyway.

The piece prints in 3 sections, the CD Bracket, the iPhone Cradle and the Lowering Arm. Due to the size of my printing bed, I had to split all the parts into two, so there is a Left and Right for all the pieces aside from the lowering arm. This piece is symmetrical and so you just print 2x of these.

The CD tray section for some reason isn't an amazing fit and on bumps and things it can come loose, If anyone has any suggestions how to fix this, let me know or feel free to remix it.

Printer:

Vector 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40

Notes:

Infill probably doesn't really matter to much.

Assembly

You need to use superglue to complete assembly.

First - Sand down all the edges where the parts join to give the superglue a good place to adhere onto

Second - Join the respective left and right sections together.

Third - Using the slightly lowered piece on the lowering arm, use the centre divide and glue the phone cradle on top the arm and allow to set

Fourth - Using the angled section, stick this to the rear of the lowering arm and allow to set.

If you get stuck, look at my images, should help.

description.text:
A simple wheel for a 6mm socked to unscrew the nozzle of an 3d printer.

This new design replaces my old on (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2085059). The old one was barely able to stand the torque. The Cube, witch transfers the force to to the socket shears of easily. This one is enforced with two brackets of 1mm wire, witch makes it a lot more solid.

The socket is locked in place with an m3 screw. The screw inside the socket also reduces its depth, witch prevent the nozzle to drop all the way down.

=> See also my Prusa i3 reworks in my Collection

Notes:

I added a small ring for support in the pocked for the hex nut. remove this with a drill after printing.

PETG is my preferred material. provides good layer adhesion with reasonable heat resistance.

Remove the Ring in the pocked for the hex nut with a drill (5.5mm)

Bend two brackets from 1mm wire as shown in the pictures and insert it to the holes like shown.

i have made this cap for covering a outdoor faucet
the outward dimensions are 127 mm x 187 mm x 110 mm

This is a small case to minimize the risk of comming into direct contact with live wires connected by terminal block.

The cross in the middle will grib onto the clamp.
The entry and exit holes for the cables are only for flat cables and it's slightly narrower in order to hold the cable firmly in placebit titer than the cable to hold it at place.

Don't want to use screws? Print the hinged version! ;) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2328109
CCSS

Storage Room Light One of my first designed prints for my purpose and not for the printer itself ^^ Needed a lamp for my storage room, so I bought a lamp socket and an "Eurostecker" with a switch at the hardware store. The socket came already with a screw clamp.

OpenSCAD I used OpenSCAD (http://www.openscad.org), an open source CAD tool which works with code.
It is very easy to use and I think a good tool to learn super basic programming with fast results. It reminds me on processing (https://processing.org) by its simplicity. I wrote everything in variables, so the size for the screws can be modified for example. The coned cylinders for the screws do not touch each other, so the two parts can be pressed to gether by the screw. The version to download is newer than the one on the pictures.
I added some guiding pins, to hold the two parts in position.

I used simple PLA for the object.
The screws are 4x20mm for wood (if you want to use other screws, you have to modiffied the code.
The rest is in the overview.

https://youtu.be/RQBocHWc3NA
The intelligent puppy on the platform (or whatever you put up there) will know which switch was operated by you and will switch it off, also when it happened behind his back.
The platform can be adjusted in height to make sure only the very top of the switches is hit.
It rotates in the wrong direction? Just switch the motor wires.
Puppy: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:220609\

If you have electronic skills, you can make the puppy bark when he moves (IC HK637-1)

title: E3D clone Zero offset mount with integrated 2n1 40mm fan cooler

description.text:
After using both of these together I decided it would be easier and more durable to combine them into less parts.

If you find any issues or problems please let me know in the comments and I'll correct them!

I modified the zero offset mount for square nuts as my printer didn't have regular hex shaped ones. it will still work with hex nuts but you'll need to hold them in place while tightening!

at first I modified the stock cooling to better clip in with large bars sticking out so I could attach it to the existing clips.

then I took it a step further and designed it to mount to the top bracket as a solid piece.

I'm still fixing an extrusion issue on my printer so I haven't test printed and fit, once I have done that I'll submit pictures and take this out of "in progress"

KNOWN ISSUES:
the first version with the bars, the inside nubs are the wrong size completely. I'll have to fix this but still wanted to release the files for people to try.

5/15/17:
Added the revised 2n1 fan shroud to this concept design. it should be better for the E3d Clone cooler. I have not had the chance to test print the fit as my printer is currently down so the alignment may be off. Feel free to give it a try and let me know if it's not centered correctly and by how much!

5/21/17:

  • After fixing my printer and making one I found some tension error and alignment issues, I fixed this by simply increasing the space for the clone to fit in, as it's secured by the bolts not by pinching the cooler. This final bolt on and go version should the the final release unless someone has other suggestions or issues.

comments.text: Originally when I made this (Before the version with the block off plate) I wanted a simple way to pop the part cooler section off so I could replace it with the stock E3D cooler for printing ABS. I used connectors on the lead wires so I could swap out the entire fan and part / heatsink cooler all at once but if you know your only going to print materials that need part cooling this is a better solution.
comments.author: A_Makers_Life

comments.text: I mostly use pla with some occasional PETG printing. I'm currently tinkering with how to have a removable piece to plug the part section. Or a similar easy to switch setting for it. Overall I really like the design and its worked great for my needs!
comments.author: A_Makers_Life

comments.text:
Have you looked at my other design with interchangeable bottom sections?
Might be worth modding that one into an all in one design.
I print in PETG nearly as much as PLA and always leave the part cooling on, I just run the fan at 40% instead of 100%.

title: Giant Spiky Perko Knot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This knot was created by exporting a model from KnotPlot and then adding extrusions to each mesh face in TopMod, then printed with an Ultimaker 3 using dissolvable PVA supports (the second picture shows the newly-printed knot in a bucket being filled with water).

Inspiration and KnotPlot model are credited by my student Jonathan Gerhard; you can read about his related project on his blog Mathematical ADD here: The Perko Praxinoscope and the Shrikhande Graph.

For information about how this model was designed and printed, read the Giant Spiky Perko Knot post on Hacktastic.

You can buy a much smaller version of this knot in our Shapeways shop:

author: choi2k10

description.text: spiral

See the playing rules and history of the game on Wikipedia:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Connect_Four It makes a nice gift for friends, you can also erase the circles from the bottom of the grill support and you can write in a nice happy birthday wish, for instance. Print the components, slide the grill into the vertical holder, then you are ready to go! When you are done with the game, lift the grill, let the discs fall into the tray, then start the re-match! At the end, you can deposit the discs inside the column to make sure you do not misplace any of them while the game is in storage.

Build Instructions:

  • The grill holder should be a straightforward print on a Markebot Replicator 2 machine if you use no raft and follow the instructions on the picture attached: 0.2mm layer, 4 shells, 10% infill. The intention of adding the circles decoration on the bottom of the support is to avoid the hassle of removing the built object from the build plate or from the raft. Personally I found the adherence to the raft to be strong enough to break the structure while removing in some trials,therefore the 4 shells for rigidity and removal of raft and supports worked well for me.

  • Print the grill vertically, with no supports needed, but with 4layer shell and 20% infill (basically print it fully solid). Doing so you will not need support structures and you will get a beautiful, shiny finish on the resulting game.

  • Print the discs set twice, each time in a different color for each player, and in a different color from the grill and holder in order to get a nice contrast and better usability for the resulting game. Enlarge the discs thickness by 15-20% to avoid that they overlap within the grill, if needed.

  • Enjoy! :-)

This is a replacement food dish for our hamster, Chester. It is designed to fit into the hole in the plastic shelf.  The upper lip keeps the bowl from falling through the hole in the shelf.
Print bowl,  Fill with food and place into hole in the shelf.  Note: use some sunflower or safflower seeds to make a very happy hamster.
Mr.clean by KassandraM [created on 3DTin]

So I got tired of grinding filament with the Gregs/Wades/etc extruder so I endeavored to create my own. The goal was to make a geared extruder with a larger diameter filament driver. The work of MoonCactus with his rollerstruder inspired this. I found later on that instead of the notches he cut into the head just cutting a groove and hobbing it seemed to work really well and was easier than trying to get the notches spaced properly.
This is designed for 3mm filament and I got good results when I used it but have gone and switched to 1.75 with everyone else... for my bowden setups it is really the way to go...
Also the mounting holes are spaced to fit on the end of a Prusa though this results in the filament pointing forward like the reprappro. For a direct drive extruder check out my NEMA23 one at: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/nema23-direct-drive-extruder

Non-printed hardware (vitamens):
3 - 608 ball bearings... you probably have a bunch of these right?
1 - NEMA17 stepper
1 - M8 hex head bolt 45mm or longer
1 - M5 threaded rod or similar diameter in SAE
1 - M5 knut ^^
1 - ~2mm x 20mm bolt
1 - 0.25" tubing to 1/8 NPT Pneumatic fitting
1 - Stiff spring like from that other extruder you are replacing
1 - M8 lock nut
1 - M8 nut
So the main part to machine is the 'hobbed bolt'. I have a small lathe so I turned the bolt head down with it but a file and drill would probably work. Once the hex becomes a circle cut a notch in it that will work for hobbing it.... and hob it. If the bolt is too hard you can anneal the metal by heating it to red hot with a torch and let it cool slowly in the air.
For the tensioner carefully cut a small hole through the end of the rod for the smaller bolt to go through and put the cam on it.
The Pneumatic fitting is meant to hold the tubing with the tubing going all the way through it so the hole on the threaded side needs to be drilled through.
When adding the large gear you probably want to add some washers to get it spaced right. Use the locknut on the large gear and add the other nut outside it to make sure the gear doesn't start un-threading itself.

title: anatomically correct poseable action figure for drawing

description.text:
I was looking for a correctly proportioned articulated human figure to use for figure drawing, testing poses for animation, etc, but couldn't find any (although ModiBot http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2222384 is not too bad), so... made one :)

He's proportioned 8 heads tall, has 15 joints that allow anatomically correct poses, and stands 12 cm tall. Except when he's posing, lounging, jumping, hanging, etc, so most of the time. :)

Printed in white looks pretty much like a cartoon skeleton. I included a few variations for some body parts as he's still a work-in-progress. I intend to make a female version as well.

Since they are symmetrical i only included one of each leg- and arm bones (4 altogether) as well as hand and foot; print two of each, and don't forget to mirror!

Update: i've added a few new parts

  • an improved hand with a new forearm that even has a little elbow "bone" to stop it from bending backwards,
  • better feet with new lower leg that does the same ("knee caps"),
  • plus a new pelvis.

Update: i've added new neck- and thigh bones with a slit in the ball that makes them easier to click in place; plus a new head with improved neck socket.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Notes:

The bones are better printed with a few brim lines due to their low footprint. print the head upside down, that way it doesn't need any support.

Carefuly snap together.

title: Kerbal Space Program - TR-18A Stack Decoupler

description.text: As already stated this is a model of a TR-18A Stack Decoupler from the game Kerbal Space Program. All the relevant detail that was in the ingame model should be in this model. The dimensions used were just rough just to get the proportion right so the model is roughly 82mm Dia x 22mm. The idea is for this to be an ongoing thing so that I would eventually have a mass of parts from the game for everyone to build and print any ship configuration desired by just drag and dropping the parts in an assembly. So keep checking my page for any future parts. If interested, join my group @ http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/design-to-print/topics where I aim to help anybody with anything I can with modeling like this design.

Scale the model to whatever size you wish before printing due to the model being oversized for ease of modeling.
If model is not in the correct orientation just set to print whatever way you want.

title: Central console coin box and mat

description.text:
The central console on my 2008 Honda Civic had two problems. It was made of hard ABS injection moulded and the ash tray in it belonged to a heavy smoker.
I decided to make without the ash tray, and make a new box and mat liner in rubber for it, to accommodate some loose change and prevent the things I put there from banging and rattling around while I drive. Hope this can be useful for more people, as it is a fairly easy design to scale if required!

author: DataDisrupter

title: Extended ball chute for Lego Mindstorms

description.text:
This is an extended ball chute for Lego Mindstorms ball-shooting robots.

It has a female cross attachment at the bottom for attaching to the launcher or a stock chute. The lower 8mm of it are just for support, and you should be able to snap it off with pliers--or just cut. I recommend you first print the attachmenttest.stl file not to waste filament to make sure the tolerances on the female cross attachment match your printer. If they don't, then use the Customizer to adjust the tolerances.

You can also customize the height by changing the number of sections.

If balls get stuck inside, run some rolled up sandpaper through the tube.

You can print extra balls with this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2303422

title: Raise3D N2 Spool holder - Small Spool Mount Diameter

description.text: The end of the stock spool holder would not fit through an AMZ3D filament spool I ordered from Amazon. I designed this to allow rolls with smaller mounting diameters to be used in the filament storage compartment of the Raise3D N2. I've included the Fusion 360 file should you want to modify it for your own applications. Enjoy!

Printer:

Raise3D N2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print with the hook end on the build plate to reduce supports. Printed in PLA.
